title: Chatbot
sentence: This criterion depends on the ability of a computer program to impersonate a human in a real-time written conversation with a human judge, sufficiently well that the judge is unable to distinguish reliably—on the basis of the conversational content alone—between the program and a real human.

title: Chatbot
sentence: The notoriety of Turing's proposed test stimulated great interest in Joseph Weizenbaum's program ELIZA, published in 1966, which seemed to be able to fool users into believing that they were conversing with a real human.

title: Chatbot
sentence: However Weizenbaum himself did not claim that ELIZA was genuinely intelligent, and the introduction to his paper presented it more as a debunking exercise:

title: Chatbot
sentence: [In] artificial intelligence ... machines are made to behave in wondrous ways, often sufficient to dazzle even the most experienced observer.

title: Chatbot
sentence: But once a particular program is unmasked, once its inner workings are explained ... its magic crumbles away; it stands revealed as a mere collection of procedures ...

title: Chatbot
sentence: The observer says to himself "I could have written that".

title: Chatbot
sentence: With that thought he moves the program in question from the shelf marked "intelligent", to that reserved for curios ...

title: Chatbot
sentence: The object of this paper is to cause just such a re-evaluation of the program about to be "explained".

title: Chatbot
sentence: Few programs ever needed it more.

title: Chatbot
sentence: ELIZA's key method of operation (copied by chatbot designers ever since) involves the recognition of clue words or phrases in the input, and the output of corresponding pre-prepared or pre-programmed responses that can move the conversation forward in an apparently meaningful way (e.g. by responding to any input that contains the word 'MOTHER' with 'TELL ME MORE ABOUT YOUR FAMILY').

title: Chatbot
sentence: Thus an illusion of understanding is generated, even though the processing involved has been merely superficial.

title: Chatbot
sentence: ELIZA showed that such an illusion is surprisingly easy to generate, because human judges are so ready to give the benefit of the doubt when conversational responses are capable of being interpreted as "intelligent".

title: Chatbot

title: Botnet
sentence: A botnet is a logical collection of Internet-connected devices such as computers, smartphones or IoT devices whose security have been breached and control ceded to a third party.

title: Botnet
sentence: Each compromised device, known as a "bot", is created when a device is penetrated by software from a malware (malicious software) distribution.

title: Botnet
sentence: The controller of a botnet is able to direct the activities of these compromised computers through communication channels formed by standards-based network protocols, such as IRC and Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP).Botnets are increasingly rented out by cyber criminals as commodities for a variety of purposes.

title: Botnet
sentence: Botnet architecture has evolved over time in an effort to evade detection and disruption.

title: Botnet
sentence: Traditionally, bot programs are constructed as clients which communicate via existing servers.

title: Botnet
sentence: This allows the bot herder (the person controlling the botnet) to perform all control from a remote location, which obfuscates their traffic.

title: Botnet
sentence: Many recent botnets now rely on existing peer-to-peer networks to communicate.

title: Botnet
sentence: These P2P bot programs perform the same actions as the client-server model, but they do not require a central server to communicate.

title: Botnet
sentence: The first botnets on the internet used a client-server model to accomplish their tasks.

title: Botnet
sentence: Typically, these botnets operate through Internet Relay Chat networks, domains, or websites.

title: Botnet
sentence: Infected clients access a predetermined location and await incoming commands from the server.

title: Botnet
sentence: The bot herder sends commands to the server, which relays them to the clients.

title: Botnet
sentence: Clients execute the commands and report their results back to the bot herder.

title: Botnet
sentence: In the case of IRC botnets, infected clients connect to an infected IRC server and join a channel pre-designated for C&C by the bot herder.

title: Botnet
sentence: The bot herder sends commands to the channel via the IRC server.

title: Botnet
sentence: Each client retrieves the commands and executes them.

title: Botnet
sentence: Clients send messages back to the IRC channel with the results of their actions.

title: Botnet
sentence: In response to efforts to detect and decapitate IRC botnets, bot herders have begun deploying malware on peer-to-peer networks.

title: Botnet
sentence: These bots may use digital signatures so that only someone with access to the private key can control the botnet.

title: Botnet
sentence: See e.g. Gameover ZeuS and ZeroAccess botnet.

title: Botnet
sentence: Newer botnets fully operate over P2P networks.

title: Botnet
sentence: Rather than communicate with a centralized server, P2P bots perform as both a command distribution server and a client which receives commands.

title: Botnet
sentence: This avoids having any single point of failure, which is an issue for centralized botnets.

title: Botnet
sentence: In order to find other infected machines, the bot discreetly probes random IP addresses until it contacts another infected machine.

title: Botnet
sentence: The contacted bot replies with information such as its software version and list of known bots.

title: Botnet
sentence: If one of the bots' version is lower than the other, they will initiate a file transfer to update.

title: Botnet
sentence: This way, each bot grows its list of infected machines and updates itself by periodically communicating to all known bots.

title: Botnet
sentence: A botnet's originator (known as a "bot herder" or "bot master") controls the botnet remotely.

title: Botnet
sentence: This is known as the command-and-control (C&C).

title: Expert system
sentence: Expert systems were formally introduced around 1965 by the Stanford Heuristic Programming Project led by Edward Feigenbaum, who is sometimes termed the "father of expert systems"; other key early contributors were Bruce Buchanan and Randall Davis.

title: Expert system
sentence: The Stanford researchers tried to identify domains where expertise was highly valued and complex, such as diagnosing infectious diseases (Mycin) and identifying unknown organic molecules (Dendral).

title: Expert system
sentence: The idea that "intelligent systems derive their power from the knowledge they possess rather than from the specific formalisms and inference schemes they use" – as Feigenbaum said – was at the time a significant step forward, since the past research had been focused on heuristic computational methods, culminating in attempts to develop very general-purpose problem solvers (foremostly the conjunct work of Allen Newell and Herbert Simon).

title: Expert system
sentence: A knowledge-based system is essentially composed of two sub-systems: the knowledge base and the inference engine.

title: Expert system
sentence: The knowledge base represents facts about the world.

title: Expert system
sentence: In early expert systems such as Mycin and Dendral, these facts were represented mainly as flat assertions about variables.

title: Expert system
sentence: In later expert systems developed with commercial shells, the knowledge base took on more structure and used concepts from object-oriented programming.

title: Expert system
sentence: The world was represented as classes, subclasses, and instances and assertions were replaced by values of object instances.

title: Expert system
sentence: The rules worked by querying and asserting values of the objects.

title: Expert system
sentence: The inference engine is an automated reasoning system that evaluates the current state of the knowledge-base, applies relevant rules, and then asserts new knowledge into the knowledge base.

title: Expert system
sentence: The inference engine may also include abilities for explanation, so that it can explain to a user the chain of reasoning used to arrive at a particular conclusion by tracing back over the firing of rules that resulted in the assertion.

title: Expert system
sentence: There are mainly two modes for an inference engine: forward chaining and backward chaining.

title: Expert system
sentence: The different approaches are dictated by whether the inference engine is being driven by the antecedent (left hand side) or the consequent (right hand side) of the rule.

title: Expert system
sentence: In forward chaining an antecedent fires and asserts the consequent.

title: Expert system
sentence: As expert systems evolved, many new techniques were incorporated into various types of inference engines.

title: Expert system

Some of the most important of these were:

Truth maintenance.

title: Expert system
sentence: These systems record the dependencies in a knowledge-base so that when facts are altered, dependent knowledge can be altered accordingly.

title: Expert system
sentence:
For example, if the system learns that Socrates is no longer known to be a man it will revoke the assertion that Socrates is mortal.
Hypothetical reasoning.

title: Expert system
sentence: In this, the knowledge base can be divided up into many possible views, a.k.a. worlds.

title: Expert system
sentence: This allows the inference engine to explore multiple possibilities in parallel.

title: Expert system
sentence: For example, the system may want to explore the consequences of both assertions, what will be true if Socrates is a Man and what will be true if he is not?

title: Expert system
sentence: Uncertainty systems.

title: Expert system
sentence: One of the first extensions of simply using rules to represent knowledge was also to associate a probability with each rule.

title: Expert system
sentence: So, not to assert that Socrates is mortal, but to assert Socrates may be mortal with some probability value.

title: Expert system
sentence: Simple probabilities were extended in some systems with sophisticated mechanisms for uncertain reasoning, such as Fuzzy logic, and combination of probabilities.

sentence: Ontology classification.

title: Expert system
sentence: With the addition of object classes to the knowledge base, a new type of reasoning was possible.

title: Expert system
sentence: Along with reasoning simply about object values, the system could also reason about object structures.

title: Expert system
sentence: In this simple example, Man can represent an object class and R1 can be redefined as a rule that defines the class of all men.

title: Expert system
sentence: These types of special purpose inference engines are termed classifiers.

title: Expert system

title: Expert system
sentence: The goal of knowledge-based systems is to make the critical information required for the system to work explicit rather than implicit.

title: Expert system
sentence: In a traditional computer program the logic is embedded in code that can typically only be reviewed by an IT specialist.

title: Expert system
sentence: With an expert system the goal was to specify the rules in a format that was intuitive and easily understood, reviewed, and even edited by domain experts rather than IT experts.

title: Expert system
sentence: The benefits of this explicit knowledge representation were rapid development and ease of maintenance.

title: Expert system
sentence: Ease of maintenance is the most obvious benefit.

title: Expert system
sentence: This was achieved in two ways.

title: Expert system
sentence: First, by removing the need to write conventional code, many of the normal problems that can be caused by even small changes to a system could be avoided with expert systems.

title: Expert system
sentence: Essentially, the logical flow of the program (at least at the highest level) was simply a given for the system, simply invoke the inference engine.

title: Expert system
sentence: This also was a reason for the second benefit: rapid prototyping.

title: Expert system
sentence: With an expert system shell it was possible to enter a few rules and have a prototype developed in days rather than the months or year typically associated with complex IT projects.

title: Expert system
sentence: A claim for expert system shells that was often made was that they removed the need for trained programmers and that experts could develop systems themselves.

title: Expert system
sentence: In reality, this was seldom if ever true.

title: Expert system
sentence: While the rules for an expert system were more comprehensible than typical computer code, they still had a formal syntax where a misplaced comma or other character could cause havoc as with any other computer language.

title: Expert system
sentence: Also, as expert systems moved from prototypes in the lab to deployment in the business world, issues of integration and maintenance became far more critical.

title: Expert system
sentence: Inevitably demands to integrate with, and take advantage of, large legacy databases and systems arose.

title: Expert system
sentence: To accomplish this, integration required the same skills as any other type of system.

title: Expert system
sentence: The most common disadvantage cited for expert systems in the academic literature is the knowledge acquisition problem.

title: Expert system
sentence: Obtaining the time of domain experts for any software application is always difficult, but for expert systems it was especially difficult because the experts were by definition highly valued and in constant demand by the organization.

title: Expert system
sentence: As a result of this problem, a great deal of research in the later years of expert systems was focused on tools for knowledge acquisition, to help automate the process of designing, debugging, and maintaining rules defined by experts.

title: Expert system
sentence: However, when looking at the life-cycle of expert systems in actual use, other problems – essentially the same problems as those of any other large system – seem at least as critical as knowledge acquisition: integration, access to large databases, and performance.

title: Expert system
sentence: Performance could be especially problematic because early expert systems were built using tools (such as earlier Lisp versions) that interpreted code expressions without first compiling them.

title: Expert system
sentence: This provided a powerful development environment, but with the drawback that it was virtually impossible to match the efficiency of the fastest compiled languages (such as C).

title: Expert system
sentence: System and database integration were difficult for early expert systems because the tools were mostly in languages and platforms that were neither familiar to nor welcome in most corporate IT environments – programming languages such as Lisp and Prolog, and hardware platforms such as Lisp machines and personal computers.

title: Expert system
sentence: As a result, much effort in the later stages of expert system tool development was focused on integrating with legacy environments such as COBOL and large database systems, and on porting to more standard platforms.

title: Expert system
sentence: These issues were resolved mainly by the client-server paradigm shift, as PCs were gradually accepted in the IT environment as a legitimate platform for serious business system development and as affordable minicomputer servers provided the processing power needed for AI applications.

title: Expert system
sentence: Another major challenge of expert systems emerges when the size of the knowledge base increases.

title: Expert system
sentence: This causes the processing complexity to increase.

title: Expert system

title: Computer facial animation

title: Computer facial animation
sentence: A major group of these Action Units represent primitive movements of facial muscles in actions such as raising brows, winking, and talking.

title: Computer facial animation
sentence: Eight AU's are for rigid three-dimensional head movements, (i.e. turning and tilting left and right and going up, down, forward and backward).

title: Computer facial animation
sentence: FACS has been successfully used for describing desired movements of synthetic faces and also in tracking facial activities.

title: Computer facial animation

title: Computer facial animation
sentence: Often visemes are used to represent the key poses in observed speech (i.e. the position of the lips, jaw and tongue when producing a particular phoneme), however there is a great deal of variation in the realisation of visemes during the production of natural speech.

title: Computer facial animation
sentence: The source of this variation is termed coarticulation which is the influence of surrounding visemes upon the current viseme (i.e. the effect of context).

title: Computer facial animation
sentence: To account for coarticulation current systems either explicitly take into account context when blending viseme keyframes or use longer units such as diphone, triphone, syllable or even word and sentence-length units.

title: Computer facial animation
sentence: One of the most common approaches to speech animation is the use of dominance functions introduced by Cohen and Massaro.

title: Computer facial animation
sentence: Each dominance function represents the influence over time that a viseme has on a speech utterance.

title: Computer facial animation
sentence: Typically the influence will be greatest at the center of the viseme and will degrade with distance from the viseme center.

title: Computer facial animation
sentence: Dominance functions are blended together to generate a speech trajectory in much the same way that spline basis functions are blended together to generate a curve.

title: Computer facial animation
sentence: The shape of each dominance function will be different according to both which viseme it represents and what aspect of the face is being controlled (e.g. lip width, jaw rotation etc.).

title: Computer facial animation
sentence: This approach to computer-generated speech animation can be seen in the Baldi talking head.

title: Computer facial animation
sentence: Other models of speech use basis units which include context (e.g. diphones, triphones etc.) instead of visemes.

title: Computer facial animation

sentence: Machine learning and data mining often employ the same methods and overlap significantly, but while machine learning focuses on prediction, based on known properties learned from the training data, data mining focuses on the discovery of (previously) unknown properties in the data (this is the analysis step of knowledge discovery in databases).

title: Applications of machine learning
sentence: Data mining uses many machine learning methods, but with different goals; on the other hand, machine learning also employs data mining methods as "unsupervised learning" or as a preprocessing step to improve learner accuracy.

sentence: Much of the confusion between these two research communities (which do often have separate conferences and separate journals, ECML PKDD being a major exception) comes from the basic assumptions they work with: in machine learning, performance is usually evaluated with respect to the ability to reproduce known knowledge, while in knowledge discovery and data mining (KDD) the key task is the discovery of previously unknown knowledge.

title: Applications of machine learning
sentence: Evaluated with respect to known knowledge, an uninformed (unsupervised) method will easily be outperformed by other supervised methods, while in a typical KDD task, supervised methods cannot be used due to the unavailability of training data.

title: Applications of machine learning
sentence: The difference between the two fields arises from the goal of generalization: while optimization algorithms can minimize the loss on a training set, machine learning is concerned with minimizing the loss on unseen samples.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: Deep learning is a class of machine learning algorithms that uses multiple layers to progressively extract higher level features from the raw input.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: For example, in image processing, lower layers may identify edges, while higher layers may identify the concepts relevant to a human such as digits or letters or faces.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: Most modern deep learning models are based on artificial neural networks, specifically, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN)s, although they can also include propositional formulas or latent variables organized layer-wise in deep generative models such as the nodes in deep belief networks and deep Boltzmann machines.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: In deep learning, each level learns to transform its input data into a slightly more abstract and composite representation.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: In an image recognition application, the raw input may be a matrix of pixels; the first representational layer may abstract the pixels and encode edges; the second layer may compose and encode arrangements of edges; the third layer may encode a nose and eyes; and the fourth layer may recognize that the image contains a face.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: Importantly, a deep learning process can learn which features to optimally place in which level on its own.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: (Of course, this does not completely eliminate the need for hand-tuning; for example, varying numbers of layers and layer sizes can provide different degrees of abstraction.)The word "deep" in "deep learning" refers to the number of layers through which the data is transformed.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: More precisely, deep learning systems have a substantial credit assignment path (CAP) depth.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: The CAP is the chain of transformations from input to output.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: CAPs describe potentially causal connections between input and output.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: For a feedforward neural network, the depth of the CAPs is that of the network and is the number of hidden layers plus one (as the output layer is also parameterized).

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: For recurrent neural networks, in which a signal may propagate through a layer more than once, the CAP depth is potentially unlimited.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: No universally agreed upon threshold of depth divides shallow learning from deep learning, but most researchers agree that deep learning involves CAP depth higher than 2.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: CAP of depth 2 has been shown to be a universal approximator in the sense that it can emulate any function.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: Beyond that, more layers do not add to the function approximator ability of the network.

title: Applications of deep learning
sentence: Deep models (CAP > 2) are able to extract better features than shallow models and hence, extra layers help in learning the features effectively.
